abstract.p: DDB Worldwide Communications Group names Ken Kaess, president, to additional post of chief executive; Kaess suceeds Keith Reinhard, who will continue as chairman; Bernard Brochand and John Bradstock are each named vice chairman (S)

block.p: The DDB Worldwide Communications Group in New York is reorganizing top management as part of a planned succession.

DDB, part of the Omnicom Group, named Ken Kaess, president, to the additional post of chief executive, effective on Jan. 1. Mr. Kaess, 46, succeeds Keith Reinhard, who has been chief executive since the agency was created by a merger in 1986. Mr. Reinhard, 65, will continue as chairman.
The DDB Worldwide Communications Group in New York is reorganizing top management as part of a planned succession.

DDB, part of the Omnicom Group, named Ken Kaess, president, to the additional post of chief executive, effective on Jan. 1. Mr. Kaess, 46, succeeds Keith Reinhard, who has been chief executive since the agency was created by a merger in 1986. Mr. Reinhard, 65, will continue as chairman.
The appointment of Mr. Kaess has been expected since May 1999, when Mr. Reinhard named Mr. Kaess chairman of a worldwide operating committee.

In addition, Bernard Brochand, 62, president for DDB International, based in Paris, and John Bradstock, 66, president for North America and the Pacific, based in Dallas and New York, were each named a vice chairman.

Their previous geographic responsibilities will now be divided regionally: James Best, 46, chief strategic officer, based in London, was named regional head for Australia/New Zealand, India, Middle East/Africa and the United Kingdom; Michael Bray, 49, president for international brands, based in London, was named regional head for Asia; Herve Brossard, 51, continues as president for Continental Europe; and Alan Pilkington, 57, based in Chicago, continues as president for North America and South America.
